revision.text:
The '''secular movement''' refers to a social and political trend in the [[United States]],<ref name="Secular Movement here to stay">{{cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/our-humanity-naturally/201301/why-the-secular-movement-is-here-stay/|title= Secular movement|publisher= Psychology Today|accessdate=2015-04-14}}</ref> beginning in the early years of the 21st century, with the founding of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Atheism]] in 1925 and the [[American Humanist Association]] in 1941, in which [[atheist]]s, [[agnostic]]s, [[secular humanist]]s, [[freethought|freethinkers]], and other [[nonreligious]] and [[nontheistic]] [[Americans]] have grown in both numbers and visibility.<ref name="Secular Movement">{{cite web|title=Secular Movement|url=http://www.thearda.com/timeline/movements/movement_59.asp|publisher= The Association of Religious Data Archives}}</ref> There has been a sharp increase in the number of Americans who identify as religiously unaffiliated, from under 10 percent in the 1990s to 20 percent in 2013.<ref name="pewforum.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2012/10/09/nones-on-the-rise/|title="Nones" on the Rise|date=9 October 2012|work=Pew Research Center's Religion & Public Life Project}}</ref> The trend is especially pronounced among young people, with about one in three Americans younger than 30 identifying as religiously unaffiliated, a figure that has nearly tripled since the 1990s.<ref name="pewforum.org"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.patheos.com/blogs/blackwhiteandgray/2013/03/trends-in-the-religious-unaffiliated-the-nones-by-age/|title=Trends in the Religious Unaffiliated, the "Nones," by Age|work=Black, White and Gray}}</ref>
The secular movement in the United States has caused friction in the [[culture war]] and in other areas of American society. It is generally opposed to the [[Christian right]] and promotes [[Liberalism in the United States|liberal]] positions on social issues such as [[LGBT rights in the United States|gay rights]], [[reproductive rights]], and [[separation of church and state]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/majority-of-atheists-are-liberal/article/2510230|title=Majority of atheists are liberal|author=Paul Bedard|work=Washington Examiner}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2012/10/09/nones-on-the-rise-social-and-political-views/|title=Social and Political Views of the Unaffiliated|date=9 October 2012|work=Pew Research Center's Religion & Public Life Project}}</ref> This doesn't mean that all "secularists" believe these things, just the movement as a whole has moved in a more "liberal" or "civil libertarian" direction.
== Organizations == The secular movement has involved the rapid growth of national and local atheist, agnostic, freethinker, and humanist groups, with organizations such as [[American Atheists]], the [[American Humanist Association]], the [[Freedom from Religion Foundation|Freedom From Religion Foundation]], and the [[Atheist Republic]] reporting rising membership and like-minded groups appearing in communities around the country.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/27/us/27atheist.html?_r=0</ref> This trend has been aided in part by the [[Internet]], which has allowed atheists and other secularists to connect through blogs and [[social media]] websites such as [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], and [[Meetup (website)|Meetup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meetup.com|title=Find your people - Meetup|work=meetup.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.patheos.com/blogs/friendlyatheist/|title=Friendly Atheist|work=Friendly Atheist}}</ref> This has enabled the formation of secular groups even in conservative, [[Bible Belt]] areas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meetup.com/atheists-64/|title=Freethought Society of the Midlands (FSM)|work=Meetup}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/Alabama-Atheists-and-Agnostics/209597389100821|title=Alabama Atheists and Agnostics|work=Facebook}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meetup.com/atheists-131/|title=Mississippi Gulf Coast Atheist and Freethinking Association|work=Meetup}}</ref> National secular groups that once had constituencies of a few thousand have used social media to attract followings in the hundreds of thousands.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/americanhumanist|title=American Humanist Association|work=Facebook}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/4ffrf|title=Freedom From Religion Foundation|work=Facebook}}</ref> Secular student groups in colleges and high schools have also seen rapid growth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishworldreview.com/0712/atheists_high_school.php3#.VPB-8bPF-Ac|title=This fall, get ready for more atheist clubs at high schools|work=jewishworldreview.com}}</ref> The [[Secular Student Alliance]], a national group formed in 2001, grew from 80 campus affiliates in 2007 to almost 400 in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2013/02/16/non_believers_taking_college_campuses_by_storm_partner/|title=Non-believers taking college campuses by storm|work=salon.com}}</ref>
In 2014, reflecting an approach similar to the "[[coming out]]" strategy of the gay rights movement, a group called Openly Secular was formed to encourage nonreligious and nontheistic Americans to speak out. The group's mission "is to eliminate discrimination and increase acceptance by getting secular people—including atheists, freethinkers, agnostics, humanists, and nonreligious people—to be open about their beliefs."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.openlysecular.org/about|title=Openly Secular|work=openlysecular.org}}</ref> In one video produced for the group, comedian and television personality [[Bill Maher]] urged atheists to be open about their [[religious skepticism]], dismissing the [[Bible]] as a book "based on ancient myths".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/bill-maher-urges-atheists-to-speak-up-knocks-the-bible-as-book-based-on-ancient-myths-in-new-ad-for-openly-secular-132831/|title=Bill Maher Urges Atheists to Speak Up; Knocks the Bible as Book Based on 'Ancient Myths' in New Ad for Openly Secular|work=Christian Post}}</ref>
== Advertising == The secular movement works to increase the visibility of nonbelievers, including through [[Advertising campaign|advertising campaigns]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/atheist.christmas.billboard.ads.target.americas.bible.belt/43768.htm|title=Atheist Christmas billboard ads target America's Bible Belt - Christian News on Christian Today|work=christiantoday.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ffrf.org/news/news-releases/item/20732-first-%E2%80%98atheist-ad%E2%80%99-on-%E2%80%98daily-show%E2%80%99-%E2%80%98colbert-report%E2%80%99-features-ron-reagan|title=First ‘atheist ad’ on ‘Daily Show,’ ‘Colbert Report’ features Ron Reagan|work=ffrf.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanhumanist.org/news/details/2010-11-humanists-launch-largest-national-advertising-campai|title=Humanists Launch Largest National Advertising Campaign Critical of Religious Scripture|work=American Humanist Association}}</ref> With the number of local secular groups growing, a national group, the [[United Coalition of Reason]], was formed in 2009 to use advertising as a means of promoting those groups. It operates by entering a media market and working with local atheist and humanist groups to form a local "Coalition of Reason", and then purchasing local advertising, usually [[Billboard|billboards]] or transit ads, to promote that coalition. The group has executed this strategy in over 75 media markets in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unitedcor.org/national/page/home|title=Home|work=unitedcor.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224083647/http://unitedcor.org/national/page/home|archivedate=2015-02-24|df=}}</ref> Typical ads convey messages such as "Are You Good Without God? Millions Are" and "Don't believe in God? You are not alone." These ads often create local controversies, and have sometimes been vandalized.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://illinoisreview.typepad.com/illinoisreview/2014/12/atheist-groups-anti-god-sign-vandalized-in-arlington-heights.html|title=Illinois atheist group's|work=Illinois Review}}</ref>
== Political involvement == In 2002, the [[Secular Coalition for America]] was formed to lobby on behalf of secular Americans in [[Washington, D.C.]] In 2007, as a result of a campaign by the group, Rep. [[Pete Stark]] of California became the first open atheist in the [[United States Congress]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/politics/article/Stark-s-atheist-views-break-political-taboo-2570270.php|title=Stark's atheist views break political taboo|work=SFGate}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.secular.org/news/pete_stark_070312.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928021401/http://www.secular.org/news/pete_stark_070312.html|title=Rep. Pete Stark (D-Cal.): first openly nontheistic member of Congress|archivedate=28 September 2007|work=secular.org}}</ref> In 2013, a political action committee was launched to support nonreligious political candidates and candidates sympathetic to atheist and humanist concerns.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/itsallpolitics/2013/09/18/223784072/atheists-start-pac-to-elect-non-religious-candidates.|title=Atheists Start PAC To Elect Nonreligious Candidates|date=18 September 2013|work=NPR.org}}</ref> The Secular Coalition for America claims that over two dozen members of Congress have privately reported being atheists, but refrain from openly identifying as such.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/group-claims-28-atheists-in-congress-27-closeted-57292/|title=Group Claims 28 Atheists in Congress; 27 Closeted|work=Christian Post}}</ref>
Although open atheists are still rarely elected in American politics, atheists frequently challenge religious conservatives on political issues. The American Humanist Association wrote letters in 2013 and 2015 to discourage newly elected members of Congress from joining the [[Congressional Prayer Caucus]], which advocates for more prayer and religion in American government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2015/02/25/atheists-say-prayer-caucus-a-threat-to-us-constitution/|title=Atheists Say Prayer Caucus A Threat To US Constitution|work=The Daily Caller}}</ref>
== Lawsuits == As America's secular demographic has grown and become more visible and active, a number of lawsuits have been brought to challenge references to God and religion in government. These cases have had limited success.
In 2002, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] ruled that the inclusion of the words "under God" in the [[Pledge of Allegiance (United States)|Pledge of Allegiance]] violated the [[Establishment Clause]] of the [[United States Constitution]]. That ruling was overturned by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] in ''[[Elk Grove Unified School District v. Newdow]]'', 542 U.S. 1 (2004). The Supreme Court ruled against the plaintiff, [[Michael Newdow]], not on the substantive legal issue but on a technicality, declaring that he lacked [[Standing (law)|legal standing]] because he did not have [[Child custody|custody]] of his daughter, on whose behalf he had brought the suit. Newdow subsequently filed a second case, and in 2010, the Ninth Circuit reversed its earlier decision and ruled that the "under God" wording did not violate the Establishment Clause.<ref>http://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2010/03/11/05-17257.pdf</ref>
In 2007, the Supreme Court ruled against the Freedom From Religion Foundation in ''[[Hein v. Freedom From Religion Foundation]]'', 551 U.S. 587 (2007), which challenged the expenditure of tax money through the [[White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives]]. The court ruled that taxpayers do not have legal standing to challenge expenditures by the executive branch. In 2011, the [[Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals]] rejected a challenge to the [[National Day of Prayer]], again on standing grounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/14/national-day-of-prayer-_n_849295.html|title=National Day Of Prayer Lawsuit Thrown Out By Federal Appeals Court|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref> In 2013, a federal court rejected a challenge, brought by Newdow and the Freedom From Religion Foundation, to remove "[[In God we trust|In God We Trust]]" from American currency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ksl.com/index.php?nid=1016&sid=26823999&fm=most_popular|title=Lawsuit to remove 'In God We Trust' from money gets dismissed - KSL.com|work=ksl.com}}</ref>
In 2014, courts in [[Massachusetts]] and [[New Jersey]] rejected challenges to state laws requiring daily recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in public schools. The lawsuits, brought by the American Humanist Association, claimed that [[Equal Protection Clause|equal protection]] guarantees under the respective state constitutions prohibited daily recitation of the pledge because the "under God" wording discriminated against atheists. The courts ruled that, because participation in the exercise is voluntary, the laws do not violate equal protection.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2014/05/09/under-god-in-pledge-of-allegiance-is-constitutional-says-massachusettss-highest-court/|title=‘Under God’ in Pledge of Allegiance is constitutional, says Massachusetts’s highest court|work=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.edweek.org/edweek/school_law/2015/02/nj_court_rejects_challenge_to_.html|title=N.J. Court Rejects Challenge to Pledge of Allegiance in Schools|work=Education Week - The School Law Blog}}</ref>
In ''[[Town of Greece v. Galloway]]'', the Supreme Court in 2014 rejected a challenge to the use of sectarian prayers by some local legislative bodies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/town-of-greece-v-galloway/|title=Town of Greece v. Galloway|work=SCOTUSblog}}</ref> Though seen as a setback for church-state separation, the ruling also stated that municipalities cannot discriminate against minority faiths in allowing invocations, and atheists and humanists subsequently used it to assert their right to participate in the invocation process. Months after the ''Galloway'' ruling, an atheist gave the invocation at a regular meeting of the Town of Greece board.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2014/07/16/atheist-invocation/12726957/|title=Atheist gives invocation, first since high court decision|author=Meaghan M. McDermott, Rochester (N.Y.) Democrat and Chronicle|date=16 July 2014|work=USA TODAY}}</ref>
The secular movement has also been active in public discourse over the definition of [[Freedom of religion|religious freedom]]. Atheist and humanist groups opposed the Supreme Court's 2014 decision in ''[[Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc.]]'', which gave corporate employers the right to opt out of the [[Contraceptive mandate (United States)|birth control mandate]] of the [[Affordable Care Act]] on religious freedom grounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.atheists.org/2014/06/30/atheists-decry-courts-grant-of-religious-rights-to-corporations-in-hobby-lobby/|title=American Atheists - Atheists Decry Court’s Grant of Religious Rights to Corporations in Hobby Lobby|work=American Atheists}}</ref>
== Reason Rally == In March 2012, several national secular groups sponsored a [[Reason Rally]] on the [[National Mall]] in Washington, D.C., with a lineup of speakers and performers that included [[Richard Dawkins]], [[Tim Minchin]], [[Bad Religion]], and [[James Randi]]. The stated purpose of the rally was "to unify, energize, and embolden secular people nationwide".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reasonrally.org/about/|title=About|work=reasonrally.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402171445/http://reasonrally.org/about/|archivedate=2012-04-02|df=}}</ref> Crowd estimates ranged from 8000 to 30,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2014/11/the-origins-of-aggressive-atheism/383088/|title=The Origins of Aggressive Atheism|author=Emma Green|date=24 November 2014|work=The Atlantic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/movie/the-unbelievers/id860364931|title=iTunes - Movies - The Unbelievers|work=iTunes}}</ref> In 2015, organizers announced plans for a second Reason Rally, but did not set a date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.patheos.com/blogs/friendlyatheist/2015/01/25/will-atheists-march-on-washington-in-2016-planning-for-the-second-reason-rally-has-begun/|title=Will Atheists March on Washington in 2016? Planning for the Second Reason Rally Has Begun|work=Friendly Atheist}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://reasonrally.org/|title=Reason Rally|work=reasonrally.org}}</ref> The second quadrennial [[Reason Rally]] was held on June 4, 2016 at the [[Lincoln Memorial]] in [[Washington, D.C.]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reasonrally.org/|title=Reason Rally|work=reasonrally.org}}</ref>
== Connection to New Atheism == [[New Atheism|New Atheist]] authors such as Dawkins, [[Sam Harris (author)|Sam Harris]], [[Daniel Dennett]], and [[Christopher Hitchens]] helped give the secular movement momentum, though many American secularists disagree with the politics and style of the New Atheists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/features/8885481/after-the-new-atheism/|title=Richard Dawkins has lost: meet the new atheists|work=The Spectator}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2013/06/23/christopher_hitchens_lies_do_atheism_no_favors/|title=Christopher Hitchens’ lies do atheism no favors|work=salon.com}}</ref> Dawkins has been involved in public disputes with atheist [[Feminism|feminists]] who have criticized remarks he has made about [[sexual harassment]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thewire.com/national/2011/07/richard-dawkins-draws-feminist-wrath-over-sexual-harassment-comments/39637/|title=Richard Dawkins Gets into a Comments War with Feminists|author=Caitlin Dickson|work=The Wire}}</ref> The New Atheist authors have been highly critical of Islam, connecting terrorism to the religion of the perpetrators, and many secularists have denounced such views as [[Islamophobia|Islamophobic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2013/03/30/dawkins_harris_hitchens_new_atheists_flirt_with_islamophobia/|title=Dawkins, Harris, Hitchens: New Atheists flirt with Islamophobia|work=salon.com}}</ref> Some within the secular movement, such as the [[American Humanist Association]], have expressed "a strong distaste for efforts to propagate a crusade mentality against Islam".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanhumanist.org/news/details/2014-11-a-humanist-approach-to-islam|title=A Humanist Approach to Islam|work=American Humanist Association}}</ref> However other prominent figures in the Secular movement disagree, such as [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]], who believes that "political correctness is counterproductive" and that we must "acknowledge the issue of [[Islam]]."<ref name="Ayaan Hirsi Ali: Tackle Islam or Face Civil War">{{cite web|title=Ayaan Hirsi Ali: Tackle Islam or Face Civil War|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/ayaan-hirsi-ali-tackle-islam-or-face-civil-war/|publisher= Politico}}</ref>
==Activists & Prominent Figures== * [[Madalyn Murray O'Hair]], activist who founded [[American Atheists]] in 1963 and sued to get a [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] decision to ban [[Bible]] reading in [[United States of America|U.S.]] schools. * [[Michael Newdow]], activist who unsuccessfully sued to get "Under God" out of the [[Pledge of Allegiance (United States)|Pledge of Allegiance]] * [[Lawrence M. Krauss]], [[Physics|Physicist]] who wrote the book [[A Universe from Nothing]] to explain a scientific origin of the Universe without a God figure, and made a documentary on secular atheism called "[[The Unbelievers]]" * [[Richard Dawkins]], author of "[[The God Delusion]]" and several other books that focus on a secular world view, as well as an activist who founded [[Richard Dawkins Foundation for Reason and Science]] in 2006 whose motto is: "to promote scientific literacy and secularism." * [[Christopher Hitchens]], author of [[God Is Not Great]] and was on the advisory board of the [[Secular Coalition for America]] * [[Daniel Dennett]], author of [[Breaking the Spell: Religion as a Natural Phenomenon]] and secular activist on the advisory board of [[Secular Coalition for America]] and [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]]. * [[Sam Harris]], author of [[The End of Faith]] and has supported spreading secularism specifically in the Muslim world by co-writing the book [[Islam and the Future of Tolerance]] with a secular Muslim. * [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]], author and activist. Wrote [[Infidel: My Life]] and [[Heretic: Why Islam Needs a Reformation Now]] where she lays out five-point reformation for [[Islam]]. She founded [[AHA Foundation]] in 2007. * [[James Randi]], Former magician turned secularist who has dedicated his life to exposing psychics and mystics, author of [[Flim-Flam!]] * [[Stephen Fry]], comedian, actor, and activist. Works for [[Humanists UK]].

{{Infobox NRHP | name =The Aquitania | nrhp_type = | image =Aquitania, Chicago.jpg | caption =The Aquitania | location= 5000 N. Marine Drive
[[Chicago, Illinois]] 60640 | coordinates = {{coord|41|58|24.74|N|87|39|4.98|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Chicago#Illinois#USA | area = | built =1923 | architect= Harris, Ralph C.; Jillson, Byron H. | architecture= Classical Revival, Moderne | added = March 1, 2002 | governing_body = Private | refnum=02000099 {{NRISref|2006a}} }} The '''Aquitania''' is a luxury, 82-unit [[Housing cooperative|cooperative]] apartment building in the Margate Park neighborhood of the [[Uptown, Chicago|Uptown]] community of [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. It is officially designated on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] by The United States Department of the Interior. The Aquitania, known legally as the 5000 North Marine Drive Corporation, was built by [[Ralph C. Harris]] and [[Byron H. Jillson]] in the [[Classical Revival]] style. Its developer was [[George K. Spoor]], the co-founder of [[Essanay Studios]] and a producer of silent movies during the first two decades of the twentieth century. At that time, Chicago rivaled both [[New York City]] and [[Hollywood]] in film production, and Spoor was able to use his considerable wealth to plan and develop a property, which he felt was befitting the celebrities connected with Chicago's growing entertainment industry. A legend, which purports that Essanay Studio actors Charlie Chaplain and Gloria Swanson once resided at The Aquitania, is likely unfounded. This probable factual inaccuracy reflects nothing more than film lore since all silent film production left Chicago's Essanay studios for southern California by 1918 at the very latest, and The Aquitania was not built until 1923, although there are historical accounts of both silent-film era stars staying as guests at The Aquitania when it was a hotel in its earliest days. When the Aquitania was built, it was situated directly on the Lake Michigan shore; subsequent development of both [[Lake Shore Drive]] and the lakefront park have moved the shore some two blocks east of the building. The fifteen-story building has a courtyard and an [[Art Moderne]] lobby. Construction was completed in 1923, and it became a cooperative in 1949.[http://wibiti.com/HomePageView.aspx?v=v&c=0&HpID=%c2%b3%5eX%e2%80%a0 Real estate Housing profiles The Aquitania] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120719094859/http://wibiti.com/HomePageView.aspx?v=v&c=0&HpID=%C2%B3%5EX%E2%80%A0 |date=2012-07-19 }} ==See also== * [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Chicago]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/IL/Cook/state.html National Register of Historic Places] Cook County *[http://www.5000marine.com/ 5000 N Marine Drive Corporation] {{Registered Historic Places}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aquitania, The}} [[Category:Apartment buildings in Chicago]] [[Category:Historic preservation]] [[Category:Residential buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Chicago]] [[Category:Housing cooperatives in the United States]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2006}} In art, theme is usually about [[life]], [[society]] or [[human nature]], but can be any other subject. Themes are the fundamental and often universal ideas explored in a work. Themes are usually implied rather than explicitly stated. Deep thematic content is not required in a work, but the great majority of works have some kind of thematic content, not always [[Authorial intentionality|intended by the author]]. Analysis of changes (or implied change) in dynamic characteristics of the work can provide insight into a particular theme.
A theme is not the same as the subject of a work. For example, the ''subject'' of ''[[Star Wars]]'' is "the battle for control of the galaxy between the [[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|Galactic Empire]] and the [[Rebel Alliance]]". The ''themes'' explored in the films might be "moral ambiguity" or "the conflict between technology and nature".
Themes differ from [[motif (visual arts)|motifs in the visual arts]] in that themes are ideas conveyed by the visual experience as a whole, while motifs are elements of the content. In the same way, a literary story with repeated symbolism related to chess does not make the story's theme the similarity of life to chess. Themes arise from the interplay of the plot, the characters, and the attitude the author takes to them, and the same story can be given very different themes in the hands of different authors.
==See also== *[[Theme (narrative)]] *[[Film criticism]] *[[Art criticism]]

{{primary sources|date=March 2008}} '''Trustworthy Repositories Audit & Certification (TRAC)''' is a document describing the metrics of an [[Open Archival Information System|OAIS]]-compliant digital repository that developed from work done by the [[Online Computer Library Center|OCLC]]/[[Research Libraries Group|RLG]] Programs and [[National Archives and Records Administration]] (NARA) task force initiative.<ref>{{cite book|isbn=9783642168086|first=David|last=Giaretta|title=Advanced Digital Preservation|year=2011}}</ref>
The TRAC checklist is an Auditing tool to assess the reliability, commitment and readiness of institutions to assume long-term preservation responsibilities. Currently the repository is under the care of the [[Center for Research Libraries|CRL]] who are utilizing it in several independent projects.<ref>http://www.crl.edu/archiving-preservation/digital-archives/metrics</ref> The TRAC checklist was superseded in 2012 by the ISO 16363, known as the Trusted Digital Repository (TDR) Checklist.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://public.ccsds.org/publications/archive/652x0m1.pdf | title=September 2011 Magenta Draft of ISO 16363 | accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref>
==History==
[[File:Digitalrepositorystandards.png|thumb|alt=A diagram of the development of digital repository standards|A diagram of the development of digital repository standards]]In 1996 the [[Consultative Committee for Space Data Systems]] established a task force that developed [[OAIS]], a high-level model for the operation of archives. OAIS was accepted as [[International Standards Organization|ISO]] 14721 in 2002. The original task force stated that an independent auditing method was necessary to certify OAIS-compliance and thus engender trust.<ref>{{cite web|title=Preserving Digital Information|url=https://www.clir.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/6/2016/09/pub63watersgarrett.pdf}}</ref> However, despite the lack of certified auditors and auditing metrics, repositories were already implementing OAIS concepts and labeling themselves OAIS-compliant.<ref name="Narations">{{cite web | url=http://blogs.archives.gov/online-public-access/?p=4697 | title=NARAtions | accessdate=June 21, 2011}}</ref>
Development of OAIS auditing metrics began in 2003. A joint task force of OCLC/RLG and NARA built upon a previous OCLC/RLG project, Trusted Digital Repositories: Attributes and Responsibilities,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oclc.org/research/activities/past/rlg/trustedrep/repositories.pdf | title=Trusted Digital Repositories: Attributes and Responsibilities | accessdate=August 1, 2012}}</ref> and wrote the metrics collectively known as Trustworthy Repositories Audit & Certification (TRAC). After the publication of TRAC in 2007, CRL was given the responsibility to carry out test audits using the metrics.
TRAC is the basis of the Trusted Digital Repository (TDR) document that was accepted as ISO 16363 in 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://public.ccsds.org/publications/archive/652x0m1.pdf | title=September 2011 Magenta Draft of ISO 16363 | accessdate=August 1, 2012}}</ref>
==Process== The TRAC metrics are split into three subject groups: *Organizational Infrastructure - the repository's administrative, staffing, financial, and legal functions *Digital Object Management - the handling of digital objects from ingest to access *Technology, Technical Infrastructure, and Security - the technology used to handle ingested objects
A TRAC audit consists of a repository completing the TRAC checklist by citing they fulfill each metric. Metrics can be fulfilled by citing relevant documentation, typical practice, or a combination of both. The TRAC auditors then examine this self-audit. After an on-site visit to discuss any concerns with the provided evidence, the auditors grade the repository on a scale of 1 to 5 for each of the three subject groups.
To retain certification, repositories meet with the auditors within 18 to 24 months for a consultation. After 4 years, the certification expires and the repository must begin a new audit.
==Trustworthiness as concept== The concept of [[Trust (emotion)#Systems|trust]] underpins the relationship between repositories and their users. The development of the OAIS model (Open Archival Information System) was accompanied by a demand for assurance that repositories claiming to use OAIS actually adhere to those standards; that is, a demand for trustworthiness.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lee|first1=Christopher|title=Digital Curation and Trusted Repositories: Steps Toward Success|journal=Texas Digital Library|date=2007|volume=8|issue=2|url=https://journals.tdl.org/jodi/index.php/jodi/article/view/229/183|accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref> The team behind TRAC, led by Robin Dale and Bruce Ambacher, conceived of the trustworthiness of the TRAC-certified repositories as not only providing for well-sourced and well-formatted records and metadata, but transparent managerial procedures and sustainable, long-term structural support.<ref>https://www.crl.edu/sites/default/files/d6/attachments/pages/trac_0.pdf</ref> The TRAC creators conceived of four core principles that underpin the checklist's criteria for a trusted digital repository (TDR): documentation (evidence), transparency, adequacy and measurability.
TRAC expanded upon the previous definition of a TDR that had been developed from the seminal 1996 PDI report that first called for audit and certification of digital repositories.<ref>{{cite web|title=Preserving Digital Information|url=https://www.clir.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/6/2016/09/pub63watersgarrett.pdf}}</ref> It selectively drew upon models such as Germany's nestor, RLG and OCLC's original TDR description and the Cornell model for Trusted Digital Repository Attributes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McGovern|first1=Nancy|title=A Digital Decade: Where Have We Been and Where Are We Going in Digital Preservation?|journal=RLG DigiNews|date=April 15, 2007|url=https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/handle/2027.42/60441/McGovern-Digital_Decade.html?sequence=4&isAllowed=y}}</ref> According to [[Elizabeth Yakel]], Ixchel Faniel, Adam Kriesberg and Ayoung Yoon, it still overlooked key factors in perceived trustworthiness. They demonstrated that understandings of trustworthiness vary across disciplines, and the 2007 TRAC checklist did not address or fully weigh the impact of differences within designated communities in perceptions of trust.<ref>http://www.ijdc.net/index.php/ijdc/article/view/8.1.143</ref> Another key conclusion of their study was there is a difference between users' trust in data and their trust in repositories. Further research by Yoon identified a strong correlation between TRAC's first two metrics (organizational infrastructure and digital object management) and user trust of repositories, but little user interest in the third metric (technical infrastructure and security).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Yoon|first1=Ayoung|title=End users' trust in data repositories: definition and influences on trust development|url=https://link-springer-com.proxy-um.researchport.umd.edu/article/10.1007/s10502-013-9207-8/fulltext.html|doi=10.1007/s10502-013-9207-8}}</ref> Drawing on previous work on TRAC, Yoon identified a "lack of deception" as the key feature in establishing trust in both sources and repositories. In 2012, ISO 16363 expanded upon and superseded the 2007 TRAC checklist by adding more detailed criteria, as well as providing a new standard for bodies seeking to be certified to perform certification.<ref>{{cite book|title=Aligning National Approaches to Digital Preservation Proceedings|date=August 2012|publisher=Educopia Institute|isbn=978 - 0 - 9826653 - 1 - 2|url=https://educopia.org/sites/educopia.org/files/publications/Aligning_National_Approaches_to_Digital_Preservation.pdf}}</ref>
==Alternatives== TRAC is not the only certification system to assess the trustworthiness of a digital information system. Other systems include:<ref>{{cite book|title=Aligning National Approaches to Digital Preservation Proceedings|date=August 2012|publisher=Educopia Institute|isbn=978 - 0 - 9826653 - 1 - 2|url=https://educopia.org/sites/educopia.org/files/publications/Aligning_National_Approaches_to_Digital_Preservation.pdf}}</ref> * DSA (Data Seal of Approval) (Netherlands) <ref>https://www.datasealofapproval.org/en/</ref> * nestorSEAL (Germany) <ref>http://www.dnb.de/Subsites/nestor/EN/Siegel/siegel.html</ref> * ISO 16363 (CRL, CCSDS and PTAB) <ref>https://public.ccsds.org/pubs/652x0m1.pdf</ref> (note that this is the successor to TRAC)
Because of the time and resources required by the certification process, information professionals have also developed other models for trustworthiness assessment of digital repositories.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Maemura|first1=et al.|title=Organizational assessment frameworks for digital preservation: A literature review and mapping|journal=AIS Review|date=July 2017|volume=68|issue=7|pages=1619–1637|doi=10.1002/asi.23807|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com.proxy-um.researchport.umd.edu/doi/10.1002/asi.23807/full}}</ref> These include: * [[DRAMBORA]] (DPE) <ref>http://www.repositoryaudit.eu/</ref> * DPCMM (Digital Preservation Capability Maturity Model) by Dollar and Ashley <ref>{{cite web|last1=Charles|first1=Dollar|title=Digital Preservation Capability Maturity Model|url=https://static.squarespace.com/static/52ebbb45e4b06f07f8bb62bd/t/53765058e4b0d45559654406/1400262744481/2014%20May_DPCMM%20Background%20and%20Performance%20Metrics.pdf}}</ref> * Levels of Preservation (National Digital Stewardship Allliance—NDSA) <ref>http://ndsa.org/activities/levels-of-digital-preservation/</ref>
==Implementation and impact== The CRL lays out and oversees the TRAC metrics. To date, CRL has certified six repositories according to criteria set out in the TRAC checklist.<ref>https://www.crl.edu/archiving-preservation/digital-archives/certification-assessment</ref> However, its influence has spread far beyond CRL-certified repositories since TRAC is commonly used as a self-auditing tool, such as at the University of North Texas and Cornell University.<ref>http://www.library.unt.edu/digital-libraries/trusted-digital-repository</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Steinhart|first1=Gail|title=Establishing Trust in a Chain of Preservation The TRAC Checklist Applied to a Data Staging Repository (DataStaR)|journal=DLib|date=September–October 2009|volume=15|issue=9/10|url=http://www.dlib.org/dlib/september09/steinhart/09steinhart.html?pagewanted=all}}</ref> TRAC's successor, ISO 16363, also provides the basis of the services provided by the Primary Trustworthy Digital Repository Authorization Body (PTAB), a private sector agency providing outside auditing services.<ref name="ptab">{{cite web |url=http://www.iso16363.org/ |title=PTAB - Primary Trustworthy Digital Repository Authorisation Body Ltd| access-date=2018-03-18}}</ref> The first certification of a repository by PTAB was for the [[Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts]], completed in January 2018.<ref name="ptab.2018">{{Cite web |url=http://www.iso16363.org/first-repository-in-the-world-has-been-awarded-iso-16363-certification/ |title=First repository in the world has been awarded ISO 16363 certification |last=Giaretta |first=David |date=2018-01-17 |access-date=2018-03-18}}</ref> Beyond these direct successors, TRAC remains among the most influential resource for independent systems of self-audit and assessment.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ray|first1=Joyce|title=The rise of digital curation and cyberinfrastructure: From experimentation to implementation and maybe integration|journal=Library Hi Tech|date=2012|volume=30|issue=4|pages=604–622|doi=10.1108/07378831211285086|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Maemura|first1=et al.|title=Organizational assessment frameworks for digital preservation: A literature review and mapping|journal=AIS Review|date=July 2017|volume=68|issue=7|pages=1619–1637|doi=10.1002/asi.23807|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com.proxy-um.researchport.umd.edu/doi/10.1002/asi.23807/full}}</ref>

''' Workplace Fairness''' is a [[501(c)_organization|501(c)(3)]] public education and advocacy organization, founded in 1994 as the '''National Employee Rights Institute'''. According to its mission statement, the organization "believes that fair treatment of workers is sound public policy and good business practice, and that free access to comprehensive, unbiased information about workers' rights" is essential. <ref name=aboutWF>{{cite web|title=Mission and History|url=http://www.workplacefairness.org/aboutwf|work=Workplace Fairness|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref>
In 2004 ''[[PC Magazine]]'' named Workplace Fairness's website as one of the "100 Top Websites You Didn't Know You Couldn't Live Without." The website features articles on [[employment law]] issues, including [[overtime]], discrimination, retaliation, privacy and [[whistleblower]] rights.<ref name=top100>{{cite web|title=2004 100 Top Websites You Didn't Know You Couldn't Live Without|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,1554208,00.asp|work=PCMag.com|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref> "Today's Workplace," the Workplace Fairness [[blog]], features daily updates on employee rights and fairness issues. According to the blog, ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine listed it as one of the "Best of the Web" in 2005. <ref name=forbes-mention>{{cite web|title=WF Blog Selected by Forbes as "Best of the Hi Alex Web"|url=http://www.todaysworkplace.org/2005/08/04/wf-blog-selected-by-forbes-as-best-of-the-web/|work=Today's Workplace|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref>
Workplace Fairness publishes books on the rights of federal employees in the United States and the Employee Rights and Employment Policy Journal. <ref name=wf-books>{{cite web|title=WF Publications|url=http://www.workplacefairness.org/publications|work=Workplace Fairness|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref>
